I think another issue worth mentioning with the shake weight idea is that the energy there isn't actually necessarily clean, it has to come from somewhere, and what you're doing really is converting chemical potential energy from glucose in your body to kinetic energy in the muscles and then finally to electrical energy (+ other forms of energy as waste at each stage) the issue with this is that means that the glucose in your body is being used up and needs replenishing for you to continue shaking the shake weight, i.e. you have to eat. Food production uses significant amounts of energy and, according to a quick google, was responsible for around 9-10% of our total greenhouse gas emissions in 2017 (Lower than I thought going into this)
Essentially what I'm saying is that this method, even if you could scale it to produce more power, really only moves the problem of green energy production further back down the chain. If this is used regularly, sure, our emissions and such from electricity production drop, but our emissions from agriculture and food production rise and off set the benefits.
Still a cool concept though, and it's used in some hand held flash lights so you can recharge the batteries when you're away from electricity sources.

I think in terms of humans producing electricity like this a better method would be to use something like an exercise bike hooked up to a small generator, that way you can put gearing on the output of the bike and get the output shaft spinning faster, hence allowing you to get higher voltages and more power.

Now, although I like the idea of using kinetic energy to produce electricity, I just simply find this design a bit impractical (as diana said).
The two key parts of this build are the coil and the magnet. To produce electricity, the only thing you have to do is to make the magnet pass through the coil.
What I'm getting at is that you don't need weights at each end. The force required to move the magnet does not have to exceed the required force you need to move the mass of the magnet, or in other words, you don't produce double the electricity by doubling the weight of the moving part.
With the design Diana made, you'd have to move the mass of the magnet AND the mass of the dumbbell (which is made to be tiresome after a certain extent)
I am proposing a "spray can" design where the magnet sits inside a lightweight tube with springs attached to each end (the springs helps to conserve some of the kinetic energy by converting it into potential energy and thereby save some of the energy that would be lost due to thermal energy by the magnet slamming into the walls)
and then, of course, have the coil sitting on the outside of the lightweight tube.
This design only fixes the weight problem but if you think about it, you can shake an almost empty spray can a lot longer than a 5 lbs dumbbell. Other minor fixes could be having a coil with a lot more wiring spun around it and for example having two magnets put together on a small stick (like a mini dumbbell) which makes two magnets pass the large coil - which means double the energy per shake (plus the factor of the times the wire is spun around the coil)

I liked the video and it managed to achieve its goal of informing about energy generation and how much energy we humans use, but I'm a bit dissapointed in it. (ONLY A BIT JUST HEAR ME OUT AND DON'T FREAK OUT)

I liked the idea of using the shakeweight to illustrate how electrical energy is mostly produced and how much work you'd have to put to power a house, but it seems that it ONLY tried to illustrate the point. What I mean is that it didn't look like most of the effort and work that you put into shaking the shakeweight went into electricity in the coil, ie. it wasn't very well tuned for it. I know that would add a lot of more difficulty to the project but in the end, the numbers you gave at the end would have been a bit more accurate. In my opinion it should have been a shakeweight-like device that produces all of the resistance that you need to work out from the magnet moving through the coil. But there is a thing that does that: an exercise bike! A lot of them rely on magnets and copper to produce the resistance to turn that you need to work out, so using one could also have been a lead to some more interesting trivia. I don't know if shakeweights also function this way, but if they do, it's a shame that you couldn't use that instead of the tiny coil.

Still, just some minor criticism. I still liked the video! I'm always eagerly waiting for the next one. (specially if it's a puzzle :D)

@Physics Girl
"If I really cared, I would be an expert on the subject." - False

This mental mistake is made frequently - depth of commitment must be demonstrable by depth of familiarity and knowledge. You do have to know enough to make correct choices in the matter; but similar to the concept of rational ignorance, at some point you know as much as you need to to rationally "care" and act on it.

That would be like saying that Bill and Melinda Gates don't care about curing and preventing malaria because neither of them have degrees and career paths in cell biology and ecology. Or first responders don't care as much about the wounded as doctors because they didn't have doctorates in medicine.

Be informed, be learning, and don't denigrate concern (or interest) simply because you don't know everything.

1. "Clean Energy" and "Renewable Energy" are not the same thing. A Hydro-electric dam might be Renewable Energy, but it also dams up a river and creates a lake, which can destroy the environment near it. Same thing with windmills and solar farms. Windmills kill more bats per year than any other man-made object, and actually cause damage to the weather and climate around the windmill farms, because they stifle the movement of wind (like a forest, but without any of the benefits of tons of trees). Solar Farms use tons of cleaning chemicals to keep the solar panels free of dust, bird poop, and so on. Also, during hot days, they can reflect so much light and radiate so much heat that birds flying overhead can burst into flames and crash down on the solar panels. The solar industry even has a name for these spontaneously combusting birds: "Streamers".

2. I admire you for trying to come up with new ways to power the world. Keep at it. But don't buy into the idiocy that "Fossil Fuels are bad for the environment, and Renewable Energy is good for it." That's just patently false. Every type of energy production will impact the world in some way. The goal is not to have zero impact on the world. The goal is human flourishing. As long as you focus on human flourishing, you will not only take care of the environment, you will always try to find a cheaper, more efficient, more plentiful source of energy. And it guards against the irrational moralizing of fuel sources that we see far too often today from extremist environmentalists.

3. Right now, the only "Clean Energy" that exists in the world is Nuclear Power. It creates the least environmental impact per Megawatt.

I can't remember who did the video in order to give credit, but recently a TedX was given by someone about clean energy. He was a supporter of clean energy since he could remember, stating his parents were hippies. Some of the research he did on clean energy involved the UK's power grid. The numbers were astounding. There were diminishing returns on the productivity of both wind and solar. Plus varying weather conditions year to year can make drastic changes in yearly output. Add to that the lack of sufficient storage for extra power, and solar panels using materials requiring very specific processes to dispose of dead cells, and they look less appealing. Geothermal is nice when available, and there could be some excellent improvements in tidal power in certain areas. The best solution he could come up with was nuclear.

The 3 high profile disasters in the field were all preventable on some level. 3 mile Island was due to sloppy operators. Chernobyl was due to design and testing. Fukushima was not updated to the emergency cooling system that was the new standard. Just some food for thought.

As a person with 8.4kWh of solar on my roof (and a former power utility employee), I can tell you the issue with green energy isn't so much harnessing it, but storing it for use when needed. Electricity, like many forms of energy must be used as it is generated. Thus, it needs to be stored. Usually we look to chemical batteries although it is possible to make super-capacitors with carbon nanotubes. However, kinetic storage (is flywheels) are also possible. All of the processes are extremely inefficient. Perhaps the best is potential energy (think pumped-storage hydro here).

The Sun gives more than enough power in a single day than it takes to power the Earth for 3 months... probably even a year. So if we cannot find a way to store it better, maybe we can focus on creative ways to harness it?

I love your show but have a lot of issues with this video.
1) The power output of the shake-weight depends on the resistance(to be more accurate, impedance) in the circuit between ends of the coil. If the resistance is lower, it just makes you work harder to maintain the same voltage across the resistor. So, when you talk about a power plant or a generator, it maces more sense to talk about its capacity instead of its instantaneous output.
2)The shake-weight is hardly a renewable or green source by any means. You grow corn and use a lot of fossil fuel and other chemicals or processes that use a lot of fossil fuel to do it. Then, you eat the corn or feed it to a cow and eat the cow. You burn that energy to move your arm and force a coil through changing magnetic field. If scaled to power a house, this whole chain would only leave devastation in its wake at every step. So, when you call it your "contribution", you should know that you aren't contributing to the side you think you are.

Hi Dianna. I agree with you and I strongly believe that we have to think more responsibly about our sources/use of energy. Most people agree that depending on non-renewable sources of energy isn't the best way to go, since they will end at some time, and are frequently not environment-friendly.

My opinion is that: it's really hard to make people change from consolidated, easy-access, non-renewable sources of energy to new, environment-friendly sources. Just because we tend to be very lazy. "Why would I bother installing a solar panel on my roof, if I already get all the power I need? I just need to keep my bills paid, and that's it". I know this sounds non-optimistic, but there are so many people thinking that way, and I think that we aren't able to change that conscience in our lifetime, unfortunatelly.

But let's change to a hypothetical scenario and consider that if I install a solar panel on my roof, I will start paying 35% less on my electricity bills (or maybe more, who knows). I guarantee to you that many more people who originally didn't bother about sources/use of energy (just because of laziness) would now start to consider using it because it would bring a benefit to the "human's most sensitive organ": their pocket.

From my point of view, we are currently evolving at a rate that we had never done before, and that's amazing. But if we could not only change people's conscience, but also offering more accessible, profitable ways of changing, I believe that we could higher this rate much more. And we, as scientists, have the opportunity (responsibility) to do so!

Your guess about 35% would be almost right for Germany. I find the figures of 2016 and in regard to electricity, it was 31.5%. In regard to heating (13.1%) and transportation (5.2%), we're also still at low levels. Regenerative electricity percentage grew steadily since Fukushima, and it may play a role our Chancellor Angela Merkel is a physicist that our "Republican" party CDU took a topic of the "Green" party. Of course, protests played a role, too, and it all goes less steady as it may be possible. There still is much dispute about coal and much more to say, there is overall progress, though. In the long term even if energy consumption rises drastically there is a theoretical abundance of solar energy available to harvest in many forms. Even just the tiny amount of sunlight hitting earth has an energy of 1.5 billion TWh per year, whereas the energy consumption worldwide is only 100,000 TWh. That's the figures making me optimisitic about the possibility of 100% regenerative energy coverage.
